comments: Motherboard LAN did not work with Windows or Linux. I can only assume it is defective, considering the forums I found online. Small, and does what it should.
a cheap NIC that works as expected and I haven't faced any driver issues just plug and play
a cheap NIC that works as expected and I haven't faced any driver issues just plug and play
Great ethernet card, no problems with it yet
Not currently installed as I am plugged into my 1gig modem but I tested it and it works. Seems good.
My wifi is really slow, so i get why I have 400 ping some days and others 30.
Extremely good for price I got.
My VM's now have 1 GBit connection to rest of my network and helps a lot to reduce load on my main network card.

Again had to buy because the LAN port on my MOBO gave out on me. Works perfectly fine and didn't cost an arm and a leg. I've bought quite a few of TP-Links products, and they make some good stuff in my opinion
6 stars. Does the job well

name: Intel X540-T2 2 x 10 Gb/s Ethernet PCIe x8 Network Adapter

specs.Features: Product Type:10Gigabit Ethernet Card

comments: Reliable and simple card. Running on a restricted x4 bus (vs. the intended PCIe 2.0 x8) yields approximately 8Gbps per port, which is quite usable too.

name: Asus XG-C100C 10 Gb/s Ethernet PCIe x4 Network Adapter
comments: God Tier Network Pcie Card
My ping and Download rate are insane using this and my Cat8 cable plus 10gb network switch nuff said ***** like but it is kinda extra

I bought this card thinking I'd prepare for the future. I have a 2.5Gbps router hard wired via CAT8 cable to the card and I get the advertised router max speeds of 2.5Gbps on the LAN but my 1Gbps WAN fiber connection isn't ready in the Republic of Ireland to upgrade to faster speeds in any direction in the near future so have yet to test its limits. We will see as time progresses if this was a worthwhile investment.

Not this exact model (I used the Asus XG-C100F) but I assume it's more or less the same thing save for the SFP+ cage on the F model.
Based on the Aquantia AQC107 chipset. Tested it with a few different SFPs and it appears to like all of them, so no vendor locking here. Can run at both 1G and 10G speeds. Picked this one because it is a fairly compact card thus not really blocking off the airflow to the GPU and has a decent heatsink.
A good entry to 10 gigabit networking, assuming you have disks fast enough to make use of it.

name: TP-Link TX201 2.5 Gb/s Ethernet PCIe x1 Network Adapter
comments: A nice NIC to have an additional 2.5 Gbps port.

Great 2.5Gbps NIC. If you're experiencing any i225/i226-v issues on Z490/Z590/Z690/Z790/B550/X570, grab this and use it instead. Realtek drivers have come a long way and I've had zero dropouts compared to my onboard Intel NIC + I still get my maximum speeds.

Windows Network Stack bypass

comments:
It's a fantastic idea but not a plausible market as an expansion card. It has its own processor for computing the sound, allowing your CPU to focus on other tasks. It helps give you a minor performance boost... but? $20 network stack optimizing software such as PGWare's Throttle can achieve half the results this $100 card can do.... Bigfoot Networks (who were bought out by Qualcomm) even state they don't support Linux...
Unfortunately, no Linux drivers exist for the Killer 2100. The card was designed to improve Windows networking performance, and those restrictions don't exist in Linux, so a driver was not created. I'm afraid driver creation has ceased for this product (bug-fix support still exists), so there likely won't be a Linux driver coming.
Apologies for the inconvenience,
Ethan Senior Support Engineer Qualcomm Atheros www.killergaming.com
